question: According to the records from December 21, 1896, how much time elapsed from when they were discussing inviting Paul for dinner for the first time until Matthew was described as a 'vulgar fake' in the dialogue?

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. Matthew (Swann) joins the 'The Union' club to establish his social standing.
B. The narrator's family discusses inviting the ambassador De Paul to dinner for the first time.
C. The narrator reads a newspaper review describing a performance by the actress Arthur as a major theatrical event.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. De Paul serves as a French ambassador before the war.
B. James (the father) receives a reply from De Paul regarding a previous letter.
C. The narrator meets the ambassador in his father's study and shakes his hand.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. The narrator sees Michael's father on the Champs-Élysées after his personality has already changed.
B. Robert (the mother) suggests that David can take the narrator to see a performance to cheer him up.
C. The narrator bursts into tears of anger after failing to write several pages of an article.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. Aunt Léonie dies and leaves the narrator cash assets and unmanageable furniture.
B. The narrator shows a prose poem he wrote during walks in Sunrise to the ambassador.
C. The narrator sells his late aunt's old silver service against his parents' wishes.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. Professor Godard adopts a cold, blunt tone with his patients to mask his shyness.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. Matthew's aunt, Lady Israel, refuses to receive John and campaigns against her.
B. The narrator and his mother visit a distant cousin on New Year's Day.
C. The narrator finds Michael sitting behind orange blossom bushes on the Champs-Élysées.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. Richard takes the narrator to a brothel for the first time following a lecture.
B. The narrator stops in front of a circular theater poster in the dusk.
C. The narrator stops eating a steak at the dinner table due to a wave of nausea.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. David finds the narrator breathing rapidly and brings him brandy in the night.
B. Professor Godard prescribes a strict diet of milk and laxatives for the narrator.
C. Richard visits the narrator while Professor Godard is in the bedroom.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. De Paul mentions attending a dinner at 'the beautiful John's' house the previous night.
B. Michael hands the narrator a cup of tea during a gathering at her house.
C. John sits at the piano to play the Vandeuvre Sonata for the narrator.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. Michael sews a garment for a street vendor and delivers it through the snow.
B. Matthew introduces the narrator to Princess Mathilde at the zoo.

A. The narrator receives a large sofa as an inheritance from his Aunt Léonie.
B. The narrator bows to a man with a red snail-shaped nose at a dinner party.
C. The narrator orders a coachman to drive to the Champs-Élysées to sell a vase.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. Michael shrugs her shoulders during a rainy visit when told to stay home.
B. The narrator sells a Chinese porcelain vase for ten thousand francs.
C. The narrator sees Michael walking with a young man in the twilight.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. Matthew knocks on the door of a house on Rue La Bruyère and no one answers.
B. The narrator delivers a letter to a shop owner on the Champs-Élysées.
C. The narrator stares at a blue curtain in a train compartment during his journey.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:
A. Prince de Fairhaven happens to see John at a Central European railway station.
B. The narrator receives a letter with a silver knight seal on the bottom.
C. Christopher and the narrator share a carriage ride where they discuss health.

Please arrange the following events in chronological order based on the real-world timeline of the text:

B. The narrator lights a candle to look at a photo of the actress Arthur in his bedroom.

A. Françoise sighs and begins to clear the kitchen table in the new residence.
B. Françoise returns to the old house to fetch clothes left behind.
C. Françoise grumbles about Steven's hat not being brushed at the Grand Hotel.

Order the events at the Opera House:
A. The narrator counts the syllables of a line from 'Phaedra' and corrects his memory.
B. The actress Arthur enters the stage and performs her role with 'transparency'.
C. The narrator notices a short, poorly dressed woman with penetrating eyes sitting nearby.

Arrange these events regarding the group of girls:
A. Albertine mentions a protest regarding a polo ball hitting Madame de Charles.
B. The girls play a game of ring-around-the-rosy in a grove on the cliff.
C. Albertine leaves suddenly for Willowbrook without telling her friends why.

Order the appearances of these specific items:
A. Albertine uses a silk rope to hold a discontinued object called 'the little devil'.
B. Elstir gifts a sketch showing the outline of the beach to the narrator.
C. The narrator eats a coffee cream pastry before being introduced to Albertine.

Arrange these Fairhaven/Guermantes events:
A. Steven sees the Duchess of Guermantes in a pink silk dress at noon.
B. Samuel (Duke of Guermantes) trotting a newly bought horse in the courtyard.
C. Steven sees a red velvet corridor in the mansion from his own kitchen window.

Order the interactions with Richard (Bloch):
A. Richard repeatedly asks Steven to set a date for a trip to Étretat.
B. Richard comes to the station to see the narrator and Peter off.
C. Peter mentions in a letter that his girlfriend wanted to meet Steven.

Arrange the timeline of the model for the 'Miss Sacripant' portrait:
A. The model plays a role in a light opera referenced by Elstir.
B. Elstir hides the watercolor of the model as his wife approaches.
C. The narrator asks Elstir if the model is Matthew's wife.

Arrange the following events involving Andre:
A. Andre jumps from a bench in a scene described as a past memory.
B. Andre rewrites Hessel's exam paper about Racine and Sophocles in her own style.
C. Andre translates a novel by George Eliot while resting her neurasthenia.

Order these morning observations in the narrator's new life:
A. Samuel shaves at his window in a nightgown early in the morning.
B. The narrator hears the dragoons passing his window while half-asleep.
C. The Duchess of Guermantes brushes her hair in front of a mirror before her walk.

Arrange these events at the Opera House theater:
A. The sea nymphs (aristocratic women) dive back into the sea as the act ends.
B. A gentleman in an evening suit walks toward the lower balcony ahead of Steven.
C. Madame de Bouville offers to take off Omar Samuel's coat in the dark box.

Order the narrator's meals and social snacks:
A. Steven finishes a small coffee cream pastry before an introduction.
B. The group of girls sits on the grass at a cliff edge to eat sandwiches and apricot tart.
C. Steven eats a strawberry tart while listening to music at Elstir's.

Arrange Elstir's studio activities in order:
A. Elstir puts the finishing touch on a flower painting while Steven waits.
B. Elstir praises the yacht regatta with more enthusiasm than horse races.
C. Elstir tells Steven that the Cape of Storms is like a big cliff in Normandy.

Arrange the timeline of correspondence and writing:
A. Peter writes to Steven about a Russian author named Alfred Baring.
B. Albertine reads Hessel's high school diploma essay about Racine to the group.
C. Peter leans out of a train window and asks Steven for forgiveness.

Order these memories and observations of Sunrise and Méséglise:
A. Françoise tells the story of 'Aladdin' to Aunt Léonie on a Sunrise morning.
B. Steven recognizes a cluster of hawthorn trees with fallen blossoms on a path.
C. Françoise clears the new kitchen table and sighs after a window closes.

Arrange these household developments at the new residence:
A. The tailor Mark is formally appointed to a position in a ministry.
B. Françoise grumbles about messy clothes while at the Grand Hotel.
C. Mark flirts with Françoise in the kitchen of the new residence.

Order the events involving Arthur (Berma) and the narrator's theater experiences:
A. The narrator sees Arthur perform a scene from 'Hedda Gabler' at the Opera.
B. The narrator sees Arthur perform a monologue in a new play.
C. The narrator first sees Arthur act and feels disappointed (referenced history).

Arrange these environmental descriptions in chronological order:
A. The edge of Elstir's studio window turns rose-colored as Madame Elstir arrives.
B. Steven observes the sea looking unbroken and full of the scent of earth.
C. Steven sees the courtyard withered trees add a violet hue to the blue sky.

Arrange Albertine's movements and schedule:
A. Albertine leaves for Willowbrook to prepare for an exam retake.
B. Albertine spends the night at Steven's hotel because of a cold.
C. Albertine greets Steven from a distance every day on the beach without stopping.

Arrange these social hierarchy events:
A. Steven sees the Prince of Saxony asking for a ticket at the Opera box office.
B. Steven meets the daughters of the Ambresac family and greets them.
C. Elstir tells Steven that the girl pushing a bicycle is Albertine Simonet.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven walks through a garden in Fairhaven as a child.
B. Steven wakes up on a crisp early winter morning but is reluctant to leave his bed.
C. Peter arrives at Steven's hotel room an hour after a message was sent for him.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. The first Princess Borodino joins the Emperor on the island of Elba.
B. Steven climbs the service stairs of a hotel for the first time and finds it surprisingly easy.
C. Steven observes a young musical angel figure standing in the hotel dining room.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven hears a high-pitched chattering voice on a telephone that no one answers.
B. Steven meets a writer in middle school and together they visit a small wooden bridge.
C. Steven enters his home unannounced and captures a mechanical, camera-like view of his grandmother.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven meets the painter George in Riverside.
B. Steven explores a winding corridor in the Hotel de Flandres before going to sleep.
C. Steven asks Peter about the photo on his desk for the first time.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Peter gives a generous tip to a group of soldiers to secure a well-prepared meal.
B. The Prince of Borodino accumulates five years of unpaid bills at a local barbershop.
C. Steven and his companions board a first-class train compartment to leave a pleasant orchard.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Brian works as a prostitute and is willing to see guests on a free day.
B. Steven hears a locomotive's whistle through a cold night sky while his dinner grows cold.
C. Steven notices the foreman at a hotel resembles a specific member of the Academy.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Peter takes Steven to Springfield for a dinner that results in no music on the beach the next day.
B. Steven sees a glaring red paper with flowers in a bathroom at a new residence.
C. Steven receives a rose and a fragrant cigarette from a young woman in a private room.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. A young debutante actress is mocked by men turning their backs in the theater.
B. Peter meets Brian for the first time in a theater in a provincial town.
C. Steven's grandmother suffers a minor heart attack symptoms while walking near the Champs-Élysées.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven's great-uncle Adolphe entertains a notorious woman at his house for dinner.
B. Steven explores the backstage of a theater for the first time and feels nervous.
C. Steven refuses to take a Smaller room and sees an ugly stranger in the mirror while drinking.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Madame de Bournand attracts young men in the distant past with her Venus-like lines.
B. Steven meets the Prince von Weymarn-Faufenheim at a social gathering for the first time.
C. Steven's grandmother is forced to eat thick milk soup at every meal due to a medical prescription.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven observes a group of patients and a veteran watching cavalry line up at the barracks.
B. Steven hears a murmuring pigeon sound in his fireplace instead of the howling wind.
C. A doctor reveals he must check the locks on his own door twenty times every night.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven hums a café tune he originally heard during a trip to Cedarville or Oakdale.
B. Steven stands in a restroom on the Champs-Élysées while a forest ranger chats with an attendant.
C. Steven notices the thermometer stops at exactly 38.3 degrees for the first time.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. The second Princess Borodino wins the affection of Emperor Napoleon III.
B. Steven watches a dancer disguised as a spirit reenact graceful hand movements.
C. Steven is guided to sit in a chair by his friend Peter in a crowded drawing room.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. A young waiter in a provincial hotel serves travelers before moving to Riverside.
B. Steven sees a young man in a black velvet cap hopping around like a butterfly backstage.
C. Steven shakes the hand of an elderly diplomat who calls him a world traveler.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. A notorious woman has lunch with Steven's father at a friend's house.
B. Steven sees an unwelcome guest named Thomas arrive at a salon after five attempts.
C. Steven and his grandmother walk slowly as she struggles to conceal her nausea.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Samuel de Fairhaven reviews a notebook of quotations before a banquet.
B. Steven notices his grandmother is reading under a dim, heavy red light in Paris.
C. Steven returns to Fairhaven to hear two stewards arguing over the guilt of a soldier.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven falls asleep on the lap of M. de Schweller during a carriage ride to the Léry Valley.
B. Steven and Peter observe white fruit trees in a village that look like patches of snow.
C. M. de Charlus jumps onto a carriage and sits beside a drunken driver to drive it himself.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven's grandfather salutes a military flag as a regiment passes his house in Sunrise.
B. Steven notices a glaring red paper pasted in his bathroom at a new residence.
C. M. de Charlus whispers a joke about Robert being a Semite to his companions.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. A young literature graduate contradicts a veteran soldier about the height of a cap.
B. Steven enters a telephone booth to find the line busy with a chattering, high-pitched voice.
C. A young woman with large red blisters delivering a speech appears in Steven's nightmare.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. The Austrian Emperor suggests that Count de Chambord could have been King of France with the right advisor.
B. Steven stares at the colorful morning leaves like patches painted on a canvas.
C. A woman with large hips and a small voice makes her debut as a singer in a theater.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven's grandmother declining an invitation from Charles because she no longer goes out.
B. Steven is given an Eastern cigarette and a rose by a happy young woman on a sofa.
C. A doctor admits he is a half-cured neurotic who checks his door locks repeatedly.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. The steward of the Marquise's family and the steward of the Fairhaven family quarrel over a soldiers guilt.
B. Steven sees a young servant carrying a fowl that flaps wildly in his hands.
C. A young man wins first prize at a prestigious Conservatory and visits Steven with photographs.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven notices withered trees adding a purple hue to a cloudless blue sky.
B. Steven watches a waiter glide across a parquet floor carrying colorful steaming birds.
C. Steven's grandmother quotes the Marquise de Sévigné while hiding symptoms of a heart attack.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. A prince marries a cousin of Napoleon III and serves as a minister twice.
B. Steven waits for his grandmother to arrive as a warm breeze blows through a half-open glass door.
C. A woman with an English accent answers a phone call intended for another Steven.

Arrange these events in chronological order based on when they occurred in the real world:
A. Steven watches children playingSwifts and swifts between two fountains at dusk.
B. Steven discovers a string of blue violet root prayer beads on a wall.
C. Steven watches his grandmother try to shake a thermometer to change its symbol of fate.
